learning_outcomes.description: Work at an advanced level of efficiency and effectiveness in a veterinary or veterinary-related environment.
Successfully integrate and demonstrate advanced knowledge and skills in the chosen discipline to the satisfaction of the invigilator/mentor/supervisor.
Develop an understanding of industry expectations and opportunities available in relation to skills and knowledge attained during the Practicum.
Demonstrate understanding of ethical responsibilities associated with professional practice in the workplace.
Effectively apply information and compile case/project/other reports accurately and professionally.
Apply reflective techniques towards developing a practice of continual professional self-improvement.

assessments.due_date: Submitted by industry partner at the end of each placement
assessments.task_description:
Attendance

Students will work with the Course coordinator to design an appropriate placement plan, which will involve 100 days of clinical/industry practical placement. Minimal attendance will be three days per week unless variation is approved by the Course coordinator. Students are required to submit a diary of days attended, which must be signed by the placement’s supervisor. Attendance constitutes an essential component of Professionalism and Communication in the Work Integrated Learning Placement Performance assessment and is a hurdle (must pass) requirement.

The Course coordinator, student and placement supervisor will collaborate to ensure that the timing of the placement maximises the learning opportunities with regards case load and case variation. Students may be required to participate in on-call and/or after-hours rosters. Students are expected to ensure that all cases and responsibilities are updated and handed over/finalised in a safe and professional manner. Students should regularly seek informal feedback on their performance from placement supervisors.

Attendance is compulsory unless there are valid reasons for not being able to do so. Missed days are required to be made-up. The placement supervisor and Course coordinator must be notified as soon as possible when days are missed and supporting documentation (e.g. medical certificate or written explanation describing the extenuating circumstances) promptly provided to the Course coordinator. If missed days cannot be completed within the scheduled period of the placement, students must request an extension via my.UQ My Requests (See below – Extension or Deferral availability).

Permission to not attend one or more placement days may be granted by the Course coordinator but only for valid reasons. Again, such days will need to be made-up.

The scheduling of missed days will be at the discretion of the placement supervisor and involve negotiation between the student and the placement supervisor. It should be noted that scheduling days missed can be problematic and may not be possible in the current academic year, which would delay graduation.

Assessment

As noted above, attendance is compulsory. Final placement assessment will not be provided until all missed days are completed.

Placement performance is based on four (4) categories.

1)     Knowledge

2)     Technical skills

3)     Clinical skills (or discipline specific skills)

4)     Communication and Professionalism

Each category has five (5) possible responses based on attitude, aptitude and abilities shown during the placement. Scores are allocated based on placement supervisor feedback.

Each category MUST be passed, which requires a score of SATISFACTORY or higher. Failure to achieve a passing score, following discussion between the student and the Course coordinator, will necessitate a period of remediation, the duration of which will be determined by the Course coordinator. If, at the conclusion of the period of remediation, the student again receives a failing score, the student will be awarded a failing grade and may or may not be eligible for supplementary assessment.
assessments.submission_guidelines: At the end of the placement, UQ will send a request via email to your industry partner supervisor to complete an assessment on your performance in the workplace. Supervisors will submit this report directly to UQ as per instructions in the email. The formal feedback will be released to you following review by UQ.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: SVS Placements Team will follow up with industry partners to retrieve this assessment. Students do not need to take any action.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.category: Notebook/ Logbook, Participation/ Student contribution, Performance, Placement, Practical/ Demonstration, Portfolio
assessments.task_description:
The student must provide evidence of mastery of the advanced skills in the chosen discipline.

A competency conversation will be held with the student and supervisor and/or the course coordinator on completion of the skills book before submission.

The skills must be signed off by your supervisor and submitted to the Course coordinator by the due date. Submission may be requested as hard copy or to be entered by the student via Blackboard.

Mastery of advanced skills must be clearly demonstrated in the case logs (refer to Assessment Item 3).

Case log numbers (1-40), must be referenced in the skills list to demonstrate case involvement.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date: Case Log is due on the Placement End Date (as recorded in InPlace)
assessments.category: Notebook/ Logbook, Participation/ Student contribution, Placement, Portfolio, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
To pass the case log requirement each student must upload two (2) acceptable cases per 5 days of placement as requested by the course coordinator. This will be via Blackboard. These cases will be numbered 1 - 40 and be cross referenced in the skills list.

  • Cases selected should reflect management of patients/experiences/situations in the specified discipline. Cases selected should demonstrate your mastery of advanced skills and knowledge. Every effort to document a wide variety of advanced skills should be reflected in your case selection. You are encouraged to select cases that demonstrate more than one advanced skill. Emphasis should be on quality rather than quantity, although a sufficient caseload must be available to provide experience with all common types of cases. It is recognised that the veterinary technician has little control over quantity exposure to appropriate cases, yet the applicant is encouraged to demonstrate as much diversity as possible.
  • Drug names (generic), dosage (mg/kg) and amount administered (in mg, not ml) should be listed whenever appropriate. For example, it is not acceptable to write “induced anaesthesia”. The actual names, dosages and amounts of pre-anesthetic and anesthetic drugs should be listed.

 

Example of an acceptable clinical case:

Patient ID: 24765

Date: 10/04/17

Species: Green Tree Python (Morelia viridis)

Weight: 76g     Sex: Unknown Age: -

Reasons for Presentation and Diagnosis:

Regurgitation, hard mass in stomach area

Diagnosis: Constipation

Summary of treatment plan:

This patient was presented to the hospital for regurgitation. Physical exam of this patient revealed a 1 cm mass, reasonably firm, caudal to its coelom, which was consistent with its left kidney. To further confirm diagnosis, an ultrasound was carried out on this patient. Ultrasound revealed a vascularized hyperechoic mass in the caudal coelom.

An exploratory surgery was carried out in this patient. Prior to premedication, the patient’s vitals were taken and recorded as followed: HR 70, RR 4 and temperature: 23.8. Patient was premedicated with Hydromorphone 0.5mg/kg (0.02ml) via intramuscular injection (IM). It was then induced with Alfaxalone 10mg/kg (0.38ml) via IM and was intubated with a size 24G catheter. Throughout the procedure, patient was maintained at 0.5% oxygen due to its size and was connected to a ventilator. Patient was monitored with a capnograph, a Doppler and an ECG. The enterectomy revealed a faecal impaction, which was successfully removed. It seemed like there was potentially a partial GIT wall perforation from the hard segment.

The patient had an uneventful recovery post surgery and was given the following medications:

1.      Tramadol 10mg/kg 0.02ml IM q24 hours

2.      Ceftazidime 20mg/kg 0.02ml IM q72 hours

Patient outcome:

Patient did well post surgery and was sent home after a night of monitoring with the following medications for the next 10 days.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Each student will be assigned a series of THREE (3) clinical questions relevant to their chosen discipline which they will need to research and formulate answers and submit via TurnItIn.  These questions will be composed by the Academic Supervisor in each discipline and approved by the Course Co-ordinator. 

Each question will be worth 15%.

Each response to a clinical principles question should be 1200 - 1500 words. The word limit does not include references, tables, figures and appendices. You must include a word count on your title page.

  • Referencing must be accurate and appropriate throughout (Vancouver style).
  • There should be evidence that the relevant literature has been critically analysed and thoughtfully integrated into the clinical question answer.


The dates for submission will be:

Question 1: 30 April, 2026.

Question 2: 30 July 2026.

Question 3: 30 September 2026.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit your Assessment through the course Turnitin submission point in Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
A case report is a detailed report of the symptoms, signs, diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up of an individual patient.

 

Consider some of the following ways of demonstrating your knowledge and experience in your case reports.

  • Show how your observations, physical examination and history taking assisted the veterinarian with diagnosis.
  • Explain why an observation was important or why you asked a certain question while taking the history.
  • Describe the procedures you performed or assisted with. Explain why the procedure was performed.
  • Describe how you assisted the veterinarian in treating the patient.
  • Explain how you helped determine whether the patients treatment was effective.
  • Explain how your observations and monitoring helped the veterinarian modify the patient's treatment.
  • Explain your role in planning the patient's care.
  • Discuss your knowledge of the disease process and how it related to your nursing care, ie. what were the potential complications or risk factors, how did you recognize them, what action did you take.


The case report must be no longer than 3,000 words. The word limit does not include references, tables, figures and appendices. You must include a word count on your title page.

It is encouraged to submit these reports for publication.

This will be a different case to the case presentation.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.due_date: Negotiated at the start of Semester 2, 2026 in agreeance with both student and course coordinator.
assessments.task_description:
Each student will be scheduled to give a 30 minute presentation. This presentation will take the form of a case report. This case report is to be drawn from cases seen during placement. Presentations can be in the form of Powerpoint, Prezi or any utilised presentation program.

Guidelines

Unique and interesting case management scenarios are encouraged for presentation. There is no limitation to the species or specific scenario, except that the emphasis will be on the chosen discipline of the student and their involvement in the case. 

  • Introduction (including the unique or interesting aspect of the case).
  • Synopsis of the case should follow a standard outline where applicable. The following example is representative of a clinical case presentation (this will vary for non-clinical placement):
  • Signalment
  • Presenting complaint
  • Pathophysiology relevant to disease process
  • Triage or Initial Assessment
  • Vital signs, Physical findings,
  • Resuscitation, Stabilisation or Intervention
  • Patient care, and recovery phase: therapeutics, monitoring
  • Final Outcome
  • Discussion: Should centre on specific nursing care and interventions as they pertain to the case being presented. Research derived from various literature sources must be evident.
  • Conclusion: Should also include nursing key points learned from the case, special skills and/or specialised monitoring equipment utilised during the case management. 
  • Presentations should be created using PowerPoint or Prezi and brought on a memory stick.

If you wish to take photographs to support your presentation, you must seek permission from the practice you are attending and the patient details must be de-identified for confidentiality.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

learning_activities.topic:
Clinical Principles Questions

Each student will be assigned a series of THREE clinical questions relevant to their chosen discipline which they will need to research and formulate answers and submit via TurnItIn. These questions will be formulated by the Academic Supervisor in each discipline and approved by the Course Co-ordinator.


Learning outcomes: L05, L06

These questions will be formulated by the Academic Supervisor in each discipline and approved by the Course Co-ordinator.

learning_activities.topic:
Case logs

Cases selected should reflect management of patients/experiences/other in the specified discipline. Cases selected should demonstrate mastery of advanced knowledge and skills. Every effort to document a wide variety of advanced knowledge and skills should be reflected in the students case selection. Students are encouraged to select cases that demonstrate more than one advanced skill.

Two case logs per five days of placement will be reported, across the100 days of placement.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Case Presentation

Each student will be scheduled to give a 30 minute oral presentation. This presentation will take the form of a case report. This case report is to be drawn from cases seen during the practicum placement. This will be a different case to the written case report.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

This case report is to be drawn from cases seen during the practicum placement. This will be a different case to the written case report.

learning_activities.topic:
Mastery of Skills

Successfully demonstrate the discipline specific clinical skills from the supplied list. Consideration will be made if there has been a lack of opportunity recognised by the preceptors. The list may be audited during the course by varying preceptors to ensure that students are actively engaged and are working through the list. It is expected that students are routinely performing the listed skills and having them signed off. Students will be counselled if they appear to making unacceptably slow progress.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Mastery of Skills Successfully demonstrate the discipline specific clinical skills from the supplied list. Consideration will be made if there has been a lack of opportunity recognised by the preceptors. The list may be audited during the course by varying preceptors to ensure that students are actively engaged and are working through the list. It is expected that students are routinely performing the listed skills and having them signed off. Students will be counselled if they appear to making unacceptably slow progress.

learning_activities.topic:
Written Case Report

Students are required to submit a written case report on a case they have been involved with during their practicum. This case report is to follow the author guidelines for The Australian Veterinary Practitioner (see learning Resources on Blackboard).
This will be a different case to the case presentation.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Written Case Report Students are required to submit a written case report on a case they have been involved with during their practicum. This case report is to follow the author guidelines for The Australian Veterinary Practitioner (see learning Resources on Blackboard). This will be a different case to the case presentation.

learning_activities.topic:
Practicum

The practicum placement is designed to expand skills and experiences in the student's particular area of interest. Students will complete the equivalent of 20 weeks of full-time placement over 2 semesters and work with highly qualified staff who are specialised in the chosen discipline. A minimum weekly commitment will be 3 days unless otherwise permitted in consultation with the course coordinator. Knowledge and skills building activities and learning pathways undertaken within each elected placement venue will be tailored to suit the chosen discipline.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
